function.name: RPosCalcVector
function.syntax: void RPosCalcVector(double lat,double lon,double mag,double azm, double *clat,double *clon);

description.p: The RPosCalcVector function calculates the end point of a vector.
The argument lat and lon give the start point of the vector. The magnitude and azimuth and are given by the arguments mag and azm.
The latitude and longitude of the calculated end point are stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments clat and clon.

function.name: RPosCubic
function.syntax: void RPosCubic(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd,struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep,int rxrise,double height, double *x,double *y,double *z);

description.p: The RPosCubic find the position of a radar range-beam cell in cubic coordinates.

The function returns either the coordinates of the corner of the cell or the center point. If the argument center is set to zero then the corner point is returned, if center is set to (1) then the center point is returned.

The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell. When calculating the corner point of a cell, the beam number ranges from zero to (16) and the range number ranges from zero to one more than the maximum range. This allows all the corners of the radar range-beam cells to be determined.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.
If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The calculated position in cartesian coordinates is stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments x, y, and z.

function.name: RPosCubicGS
function.syntax: void RPosCubicGS(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd,struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep,int rxrise,double height, double *x,double *y,double *z);

description.p: The RPosCubic find the position of a radar range-beam cell containing ground scatter in cubic coordinates.

The function returns either the coordinates of the corner of the cell or the center point. If the argument center is set to zero then the corner point is returned, if center is set to (1) then the center point is returned.

The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell. When calculating the corner point of a cell, the beam number ranges from zero to (16) and the range number ranges from zero to one more than the maximum range. This allows all the corners of the radar range-beam cells to be determined.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.
If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The calculated position in cartesian coordinates is stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments x, y, and z.

function.name: RPosGeo
function.syntax: void RPosGeo(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd,struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep, int rxrise,double height, double *rho,double *lat,double *lon);

description.p: The RPosGeo find the position of a radar range-beam cell in geographic coordinates.

The function returns either the coordinates of the corner of the cell or the center point. If the argument center is set to zero then the corner point is returned, if center is set to (1) then the center point is returned.

The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell. When calculating the corner point of a cell, the beam number ranges from zero to (16) and the range number ranges from zero to one more than the maximum range. This allows all the corners of the radar range-beam cells to be determined.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.
If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The distance from the earth's center, geographic latitude and longitude are stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments rho, lat, and lon.

function.name: RPosGeoGS
function.syntax: void RPosGeoGS(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd,struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep,int rxrise,double height, double *rho,double *lat,double *lon);

description.p: The RPosGeoGS find the position of a radar range-beam cell containing ground scatter in geographic coordinates.

The function returns either the coordinates of the corner of the cell or the center point. If the argument center is set to zero then the corner point is returned, if center is set to (1) then the center point is returned.

The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell. When calculating the corner point of a cell, the beam number ranges from zero to (16) and the range number ranges from zero to one more than the maximum range. This allows all the corners of the radar range-beam cells to be determined.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.

function.name: RPosInvMag
function.syntax: void RPosInvMag(int bm,int rn,int year,struct RadarSite *hdw,double frang, double rsep,double rx,double height, double *mlat,double *mlon,double *azm);

description.p: The RPosInvMag function calculates the invariant magnetic co-ordinates of a radar range-beam cell.
The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell.
The argument year defines the year for which the calculatation should be performed.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.
If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The invariant magnetic latitude, longitude and azimuth are stored stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments mlat, mlon, and azm.

function.name: RPosMag
function.syntax: void RPosMag(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd, struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep,int rxrise,double height, double *rho,double *lat,double *lon);

description.p: The RPosMag find the position of a radar range-beam cell in magnetic coordinates.

The function returns either the coordinates of the corner of the cell or the center point. If the argument center is set to zero then the corner point is returned, if center is set to (1) then the center point is returned.

The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell. If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The distance from the earth's center, geomagnetic latitude and longitude are stored stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments rho, lat, and lon.

function.syntax: void RPosMagGS(int center,int bcrd,int rcrd,struct RadarSite *hdw, int frang,int rsep,int rxrise,double height, double *rho,double *lat,double *lon);

function.name: RPosRngBmAzmElv
function.syntax: void RPosRngBmAzmElv(int bm,int rn,int year,struct RadarSite *hdw,double frang, double rsep,double rx,double height, double *azm,double *elv);

description.p: The RPosRngBmAzmElv function calculates the azimuth and elevation angle of a radar range-beam cell.
The arguments bcrd and rcrd give the beam and range number of the cell.
The argument year defines the year for which the calculatation should be performed.
The argument hdw points to a structure containing the radar site and hardware information.
The distance to the first range and the range separation are given by the arguments frang, rsep.
The argument rxrise gives the receiver rise time, if this is set to zero then the receiver rise time will be taken from the hardware table.
If the argument height is less than or equal to 90 it corresponds to the elevation angle in degrees associated with the calculation, otherwise is corresponds to the height in kilometers.
The azimuth and elvation angle are stored stored at the locations pointed to by the arguments azm, elv.
